citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There was a king charles spaniel, female (Sassy, 3yrs old) that had dirty ears with a brown greasy material around the ear
flap and inner canal. The left ear had more than normal moisture within the ear with some redness. While the animal had
not been showing any obvious signs of discomfort the ears had not been cleaned for some time resulting in the condition
not being observed and the attending veterinarian had not been contacted for proper diagnosis or treatment.
The lack of timely veterinary diagnosis or care could cause a treatable condition to become chronic or cause unnecessary
pain or discomfort to the regulated animal.
The licensee must contact the veterinarian for proper diagnosis and treatment if required, and a routine for ear cleaning
must be regularly conducted according to the program of veterinary care.
To be corrected by: July 19, 2023
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2) more inspection(s) or by September 17, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There was a king charles spaniel, female (Sassy, 3yrs old) that had dirty ears with a brown greasy material around the ear 
flap and inner canal. The left ear had more than normal moisture within the ear with some redness. While the animal had 
not been showing any obvious signs of discomfort the ears had not been cleaned for some time resulting in the condition 
not being observed and the attending veterinarian had not been contacted for proper diagnosis or treatment. 
 
The lack of timely veterinary diagnosis or care could cause a treatable condition to become chronic or cause unnecessary 
pain or discomfort to the regulated animal. 
 
The licensee must contact the veterinarian for proper diagnosis and treatment if required, and a routine for ear cleaning 
must be regularly conducted according to the program of veterinary care.  
 
To be corrected by: July 19, 2023 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2) more inspection(s) or by September 17, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
